title: Navigating My Career With Sickle Cell

content: One area I've been reflecting on lately is how sickle cell has influenced my career journey. Living with a chronic illness affects more than just physical health. It shapes how we navigate work, relationships, and our sense of identity. For me, learning to manage sickle cell in professional spaces has been a long process of unlearning silence, confronting guilt, and eventually embracing honesty.

My first job was at the Emirates Stadium, where I served food and drinks on match days. It was part-time, flexible, and allowed me the freedom to choose my work schedule. That flexibility made it manageable, and like most young people, I was just excited to be earning money. But even then, I remember how physically drained I felt after each shift. I didn't think much of it at the time; I just pushed through.

Things shifted when I started working in retail more consistently. I took on a job in a department store. I began working both Saturdays and Sundays to fund driving lessons and cover university-related expenses. That's when I started to develop an unhealthy relationship with my health and work. I rarely called in sick, even when I knew I should have. If I did, it wasn't due to a sickle cell crisis. I'd tell my manager I had a stomach bug or the flu instead. I felt ashamed of my condition and convinced myself that revealing it would lead to judgment or pity.

content: That mindset led me to push through minor crises, limping into work, fighting exhaustion, and maintaining an image of reliability. And while retail wasn't my dream job, I still felt a need to prove I could handle it like everyone else. I didn't want to seem different.

After university, I began my first full-time role in a research and development office. I carried the same behavior into this new space, showing up unwell, underperforming, and deflecting concerned questions with vague excuses. Eventually, I reached a breaking point and disclosed to my manager that I had sickle cell. To my surprise, the conversation with my manager wasn't met with confusion or judgment. Instead, the conversation was marked by understanding and a genuine desire to help. That moment changed everything for me.

content: Being open about my health in the workplace became a turning point in my journey, both professionally and personally. Once I allowed myself to be honest at work, it became easier to be truthful in other areas of my life. I started embracing advocacy more fully. I gained the confidence to say, "I have a hospital appointment," or "I need time off to manage my condition," without feeling the need to justify or minimize it.

content: I'm aware not every employer responds with compassion. Some workplaces still struggle to accommodate people with chronic illnesses. However, that's why it's even more crucial to prioritize your health and establish clear boundaries. Yes, we all need to earn a living, but no job is worth sacrificing our well-being for. Being honest about your condition not only protects you but also helps create a culture of transparency and care.

Working during the pandemic was another shift. Remote working became a lifeline. It allowed me to attend hospital appointments without disruption and manage my stress more effectively. At home, I've created a work environment that's tailored to my needs. I have my medications nearby, I stay hydrated, and I no longer have to negotiate with co-workers over office temperature settings or deal with uncomfortable desks. These small changes have made a massive difference in how I function and thrive professionally.

There's a persistent myth that people with sickle cell don't want to work or aren't capable of holding down demanding careers. However, I know many people with this condition who are doing incredible things across various industries, from medicine and law to the creative arts and technology. We aren't limited by ability; we're often limited by systems that don't accommodate differences.

content: Workplaces have a responsibility to support their employees. That support includes understanding chronic illnesses, being willing to make adjustments, and fostering a culture of trust. When that happens, everyone benefits. Employees can perform better, and companies retain passionate, committed people.

If you're someone with sickle cell and are worried about sharing your diagnosis at work, I understand the fear. I've lived it. But being open has given me the space to take care of myself properly and perform at my best. The worst time for your colleagues or employer to learn about your condition is during a crisis. Honesty might feel risky, but it's often the key to building a career that's sustainable and fulfilling.

It's a strength. That strength has helped me move forward, not just in my professional life but in life as a whole.
